Award.AwardTitle: Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Stonehill College is providing 36 scholarships to about 18 junior or senior mathematics majors who commit to teaching at high needs school districts (including districts in Avon, Brockton, Holbrook, Randolph and Stoughton, MA). The project addresses the problems of retaining would-be teachers by developing a community of practice model to prepare and sustain teachers as they matriculate through their teacher preparation and beyond. The project provides professional development opportunities including bringing in master teachers for an on-campus Noyce Speaker Series, school-based enrichment programs where the scholars interact with K-12 students to develop deep conceptual understanding of mathematics, paid mathematics internships within local school districts, special interest housing, and semester-long or summer-long undergraduate research with mathematics or education faculty. The project also addresses the challenge of attracting and retaining highly qualified teachers in the difficult-to-recruit field of mathematics to high need schools while making an effort to attract and retain a more diverse teacher population. The recruitment of these scholars involves theme-based events while cultivating current and potential mathematics majors or students with a declared interest in education to consider joining a community of practice facilitated by the program's activities. The program's intentional design of integrating research with educational experiences enables new mathematics teachers to adopt similar models in their own classrooms, infusing education with the excitement of discovery and sparking their students' interest in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With financial assistance from the National Science Foundation, Stonehill College and our partner districts (Avon, Brockton, Holbrook, Randolph, and Stoughton, Massachusetts) implemented  Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond.

Key to our success was the creation of Communities of Practice (CofP) ? intentional communities of individuals with shared interests in mathematics content and pedagogy. CofP were available to all mathematics and education students beginning their first semester at the College and are being maintained through their transition into teaching careers. Through participation in CofP, Noyce Scholars, Noyce Scholar Graduates, as well as all licensure candidates at the College, had access to sustained mentoring from mathematics and pedagogy mentors, access to models of best practice through CofP meetings and the Noyce Speaker Series, and opportunities to participate in undergraduate research and early, supervised field experiences through NUMB3RS Projects.

These CofP initiatives served as a vehicle through which Stonehill College met our project goals of (1) recruiting diverse, academically-talented mathematics majors to consider careers in K-12 mathematics education, (2) preparing exemplary teachers of mathematics, and (3) retaining these top-notch teachers in high-need schools and districts.

Recruitment: Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond awarded 36 $25,000 scholarships to 19 mathematics majors (four for the 13/14 academic year, six for the 14/15 academic year, five for the 15/16 academic year, nine for the 16/17 academic year, nine for the 17/18 academic year, and three for the 18/19 academic year). Scholars include 15 females, four males, two community college transfers, and one student identifying as a diverse candidate. This strong recruitment of Noyce Scholars is an indication of the program?s success at assisting the College with diversifying our student body both demographically and in terms of path to graduation.

Eighteen of our Noyce Scholar Graduates are serving as teachers of mathematics during the 19/20 academic year; all but one are working in a high-need school/district. We have Noyce Scholar Graduates working in 15 high-need schools in 13 high-need districts across the Commonwealth of Massachusetts with six teaching at the elementary school, three at the middle school, and nine at the high school level. This record of strong teacher placement and retention is evidence that Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond has impact across the K-12 spectrum in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Preparation: Across the years of funding, Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond hosted 37 CofP events open to the Stonehill community (but required of all Noyce Scholars). The purpose of these events was to: (1) expose all mathematics majors, as well as all current educational licensure candidates, to best practices in mathematics education and (2) encourage students to consider working in high-need schools and districts through exposure to culturally responsive teaching practices.

Additionally, 12 first/second year students (seven of whom went on to become Noyce Scholars) participated in five different summer research projects (Noyce Undergraduate Research Experience) and 55 unique students participated in NUMB3RS Projects. Across seven semesters, 18 different NUMB3RS Projects were offered alongside six different community partners.

Sixteen Scholars attended one or more National Council of Teachers of Mathematics Annual Meeting and Expositions: three in New Orleans, Louisiana; 15 in Boston, Massachusetts; three in San Francisco, California and two in Washington, DC. Additionally, three Scholars attended a Noyce Northeast Conference or annual Noyce Meeting in Washington, DC.

Thus, Noyce programming reached a sizable number of Stonehill students from across campus (well beyond the mathematics and education departments). Across the life of the grant more than 850 unique Stonehill students participated in one or more Noyce events/programs. Beginning with the class of 2015 ? the first class to be eligible to apply for Noyce Scholarships - 86% or more of all licensure candidates have been involved in Noyce events/initiatives.

Retention: 100% of our Noyce Scholars who entered the College as first-year students graduated in 4 years. Five Noyce Scholar Graduates have already completed their required years of service, and all five (100%) are continuing their careers as teachers of mathematics in high-need schools or districts during the 2019/2020 academic year.

Dissemination: In addition to posters and workshop presentations at the annual Noyce Summit, findings from Communities of Practice: Teacher Preparation and Beyond has been disseminated through presentations at The 10th International Conference on Education, High Impact Practices, Innovation, Global Engagement and Learning (2019, June); The 10th Annual Conference on Diversity & Inclusion at Stonehill College (2018, November); the Lily Conference on College and University Teaching (2018, June); The Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators (2018, February); and the Massachusetts Association of Colleges for Teacher Education (2015, October). Six different Noyce Scholars, alongside members of the Noyce Project Team, were part of one or more presentation teams. Additionally, we had our first manuscript detailing a Noyce related initiative published in the Journal of Experiential Education in 2019.
